For example, signal transducer and activator of transcription (STAT3) binds to four different phosphorylated tyrosine residues in the intracellular region of gp130 (Tyr767, Tyr814, Tyr905, and Tyr915); two of these tyrosine residues (Tyr905 and Tyr915) also contribute to the binding of STAT1 (8Gerhartz C. Heesel B. Sasse J. Hemmann U. Landgraf C. Schneider-Mergener J. Horn F. Heinrich P.C. Graeve L. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 12991-12998Google Scholar, 9Fukada T. Hibi M. Yamanaka Y. Takahashi-Tezuka M. Fujitani Y. Yamaguchi T. Nakajima K. Hirano T. Immunity. 1996; 5: 449-460Google Scholar). Phosphorylation of Tyr residue 759 leads to recruitment of SH-2 domain-containing tyrosine phosphatase 2 (SHP-2) (10Schmitz J. Weissenbach M. Haan S. Heinrich P.C. Schaper F. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 12848-12856Google Scholar, 11Kim H. Baumann H. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 5326-5338Google Scholar, 12Terstegen L. Gatsios P. Bode J.G. Schaper F. Heinrich P.C. Graeve L. J. Biol. Baumann H. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 5326-5338Google Scholar, 12Terstegen L. Gatsios P. Bode J.G. Schaper F. Heinrich P.C. Graeve L. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 18810-18817Google Scholar, 14Kim H. Chem. 2000; 275: 12848-12856Google Scholar, 20Alexander W.S. Nat. Rev. Immunol. 2002; 2: 410-416Google Scholar, 21Magrangeas F. Boisteau O. Denis S. Jacques Y. Minvielle S. Biochem. J. 2001; 353: 223-230Google Scholar). Willson T.A. Farley A. Starr R. Zhang J.G. Baca M. Alexander W.S. Metcalf D. Hilton D.J. Nicola N.A. EMBO J. 1999; 18: 375-385Google Scholar). In contrast, SOCS-3 binds directly to Tyr residue 759 on gp130 (10Schmitz J. Weissenbach M. Haan S. Heinrich P.C. Schaper F. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 12848-12856Google Scholar, 12Terstegen L. Gatsios P. Bode J.G. Schaper F. Heinrich P.C. Graeve L. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 18810-18817Google Scholar), and this interaction is necessary for the inhibitory effect of overexpressed SOCS-3, but not of SOCS-1, on both STAT1 and STAT3 activation in HepG2 cells (10Schmitz J. Weissenbach M. Haan S. Heinrich P.C. Schaper F. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 12848-12856Google Scholar). SOCS-3 mRNA is rapidly and transiently induced by IL-6 and LIF, and LIF-stimulated SOCS-3 gene expression is at least in part is mediated by STAT3 and STAT1 (23Blanchard F. Wang Y. Kinzie E. Duplomb L. Godard A. Baumann H. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 47038-47045Google Scholar, 24Auernhammer C.J. Bousquet C. Melmed S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. 1999; 96: 6964-6969Google Scholar, 25Paul C. Seiliez I. Thissen J.P. Le Cam A. Eur. J. Biochem. 2000; 267: 5849-5857Google Scholar, 26Magrangeas F. Boisteau O. Denis S. Jacques Y. Minvielle S. Eur. Cytokine. Net. 2001; 12: 309-315Google Scholar). In this way, SOCS-3 acts as a negative regulator of its own gene expression. We have previously shown that in cultured human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVEC) OnM and IL-11 rapidly but transiently activate STAT1, STAT3, p42, and p44 MAPK (27Mahboubi K. Pober J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 8012-8021Google Scholar). Tyr residue 759 of gp130 signaling domain was demonstrated to be necessary for this transience of activation of STAT1 in HUVEC (27Mahboubi K. Pober J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 8012-8021Google Scholar), implying that the short duration of active signaling through gp130 is mediated by SHP-2 or SOCS-3. In the present study, we show that stimulation with OnM desensitizes HUVEC as well as human aortic smooth muscle cells (HASMC) to further activation by OnM. Desensitization can occur in trans, affecting other gp130-signaling cytokines, and also involves Tyr residue 759 in gp130. However, our data indicate that this desensitization is not mediated by either SOCS-3 or SHP-2, the only two proteins to date shown to bind to this site. RNA Isolation and Quantitative Real-time RT-PCR—Total RNA was isolated from HUVEC with Qiagen Rneasy mini kit (Qiagen Inc., Valencia, CA) as recommended by the supplier. Using equal amount of total RNA (200 ng) from HUVEC, stimulated under various conditions, mRNA was primed with random hexamers, and complementary DNA (cDNA) was synthesized from mRNA by TaqMan reverse transcription with MultiScribe reverse transcriptase (PE Applied Biosystems, Foster, CT) according to the manufacturer's description. The final cDNA product was used for subsequent cDNA amplification by polymerase chain reaction. cDNA was amplified and quantitated by using SYBR Green PCR reagents from PE Applied Biosystems according to the manufacturer's instructions. Briefly, the cDNA for SOCS-3 and GAPDH were amplified by AmpliTag Gold DNA polymerase using specific primers, which were synthesized by Yale HHMI/Keck oligonucleotide synthetic facility (Yale University School of Medicine, New Haven, CT). The cDNA for GAPDH was amplified by using a specific forward primer (5′-GAAGGTGAAGGTCGGAGTC-3′) and a specific reverse primer (5′-GAAGATGGTGATGGGATTTC-3′). The following specific primers were used to amplify SOCS-3 cDNA: a forward primer, 5′-GGCCACTCTTCAGCATCTC-3′ and a reverse primer, 5′-ATCGTACTGGTCCAGGAACTC-3′. The PCR reaction mixture (final volume 25 μl) contained 5 μl of cDNA, 1 μl of 10 μm forward primer, 1 μl of 10 μm reverse primer, 2.5 μl of PCR 10× SYBR Green PCR buffer, 3 μl of 25mm MgCl2, 2 μl of dNTP mix (2.5 mm dATP, 2.5 mm dCTP, 2.5 mm dGTP, and 5 mm dUTP), 0.25 μl of AmpErase UNG (1 unit/μl uracil-N-glycosylase), 0.125 μl of AmpliTag Gold DNA polymerase (5 units/μl AmpliTag Gold DNA polymerase), and 10.125 μl of H2O. The PCR reaction was performed in triplicate (3 wells of C96 well plate). The reaction was amplified with iCycler iQ Multicolor Real Time PCR Detector (Bio-Rad) for 37 cycles with melting at 94 °C for 30 s, an annealing at 58 °C for 30 s, and extension at 72 °C for 1 min in iCycler iQ PCR 96-well plates (Bio-Rad). The relative quantification values for the SOCS-3 gene expression were calculated from the accurate CT, which is the PCR cycle at which an increase in reporter fluorescence from SYBR Green dye can be first detected obtained above a baseline signal. CT values for GAPDH cDNA were subtracted from CT values for SOCS-3 cDNA for each well to calculate Δ-CT. The triplicate Δ-CT values for each sample were averaged. To calculate the fold induction of SOCS-3 mRNA in cells treated with cytokines over control cells, the averaged Δ-CT values calculated for control cells was subtracted from Δ-CT values calculated for cytokine-treated cells to calculate ΔΔ-CT. Then, the fold induction for each well was calculated by using 2–(ΔΔ-CT) formula. The fold induction value for triplicate wells was averaged, and data are presented as the mean ± S.E. of triplicate wells. Many of these are tissue (e.g. liver)-specific, but SOCS-3 is a protein, which is widely induced by gp130-signaling cytokines (23Blanchard F. Wang Y. Kinzie E. Duplomb L. Godard A. Baumann H. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 47038-47045Google Scholar, 24Auernhammer C.J. Bousquet C. Melmed S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. 1999; 96: 6964-6969Google Scholar, 26Magrangeas F. Boisteau O. Denis S. Jacques Y. Minvielle S. Eur. Cytokine. Net. 2001; 12: 309-315Google Scholar). We examined the effects of OnM on SOCS-3 mRNA expression in HUVEC by stimulating confluent cultures with OnM for various times measuring SOCS-3 mRNA using a quantitative real-time RT-PCR method (Fig. 1A). Resting cells expressed little SOCS-3 mRNA. OnM caused a time-dependent increase in SOCS-3 mRNA levels above that of untreated cells, which peaked 30 min to 1 h after stimulation with OnM and was significantly reduced at 3 h and only slightly elevated 24 h after stimulation with OnM (Fig. 1A). OnM induced the expression of SOCS-3 protein, detected by immunblotting using a specific polyclonal Ab. OnM also increased SOCS-3 protein in a time-dependent manner, which peaked 1 h after stimulation, and in contrast to mRNA, remained elevated for up to 36 h (Fig. 1B). We next examined whether OnM-treated HUVEC are able to respond to restimulation with OnM. Preincubation of HUVEC for 24 h with OnM blocked a second round of up-regulation of SOCS-3 mRNA in response to treatment with OnM (Fig. 1C). Like OnM, other gp130-signaling cytokines IL-11 and LIF induced SOCS-3 mRNA levels (Fig. 1C). Pretreatment with OnM also inhibited the induction of SOCS-3 mRNA by LIF and IL-11 (Fig. 1C). These experiments show that treatment of HUVEC with OnM desensitized these cells not only to OnM but also to other cytokines that use gp130 to transduce signals. Seiliez I. Thissen J.P. Le Cam A. Eur. J. Biochem. 2000; 267: 5849-5857Google Scholar).
